ORAL ANSWERS TO QUESTIONS

MASS RAPID TRANSIT SYSTEM FOR SINGAPORE
(Feasibility study)


    1. Mr J. F. Conceicao asked the Minister for Communications what progress has been made in the consideration given to the need for a mass rapid transit system for Singapore.

    The Minister for Communications (Mr Yong Nyuk Lin): Mr Speaker, Sir, in February last year, at the request of the Ministry of Finance, the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development, otherwise known as the World Bank, sent an evaluation

Column: 638

mission to review the studies conducted by the State and City Planning Office for an urban mass rapid transit system in Singapore. It concluded that more detailed studies were required especially to consider, firstly, the consequences of having or not having a mass rapid transit system; and secondly, the selection of a favoured system after considering the various alternatives available. The World Bank Mission further recommended that we seek technical assistance from the United Nations Development Programme to finance the cost of the proposed study.

    With the concurrence of the Ministries of Communications, Finance and National Development, the terms of references for the study were

Column: 639

finalised and an application for assistance submitted to the United Nations Development Programme in January this year. The matter is now under consideration by them and should the assistance requested for be granted, the study is expected to commence as from January next year.

    The Member for Katong may recall that the Minister for Finance, in his budget statement made in this House on 8th March, in referring to Development proposals under the Ministry of Communications, stated as follows --see Hansard, cols. 582-3:

    The new Mass Transit Planning Unit to be set up for further investigation into the feasibility of a mass rapid transit system for Singapore, requires a sum of $500,000. The study will be carried out with U.N.D.P. (United Nations Development Programme) assistance.'

    Mr J. F. Conceicao (Katong): Should the study commence in January next year, can the Minister inform the House how long it will take before the study is completed?

    Mr Yong Nyuk Lin: Sir, it was indicated by the World Bank Mission that it may take anything from 15 to 18 months.

Column: 639

ROAD REPAIRING AND STREET LIGHTING


    The following Question stood in the name of Mr Teong Eng Siong -

    2. To ask the Minister for Law and National Development (a) if immediate steps will be taken to repair Jalan Ulu Sembawang which is badly damaged; and (b) when work will commence (i) to repair Lorong Kasemek; and (ii) to install street lights at Chong Sin Road near the Huang Long Community Centre.

    Mr Ng Yeow Chong (Mountbatten) rose -

    Mr Speaker: Mr Ng Yeow Chong.

    Mr Ng Yeow Chong: Sir, I have been asked by Mr Teong Eng Siong to raise Question No. 2.

Column: 640



    The Minister for Law and National Development (Mr E. W. Barker): Mr Speaker, Sir, immediate steps will not be taken to repair Jalan Ulu Sembawang. The maintenance or making up of private roads is the responsibility of owners of the land fronting the roads. But the Urban and Rural Services Committee can help f the land-owner gives permission for the work and the constituency's Citizens' Consultative Committee recommends that the work be done and the cost paid from funds allocated to the constituency. Jalan Ulu Sembawang is a private road stretching from Sembawang Road to Mandai Road. A request has been received from the Sembawang Citizens' Consultative Committee to make up a portion of the road by gotong royong. Materials alone will cost about $64,000. The proposal will be tabled for consideration of the U.R.S.C, at its next meeting.

    Lorong Kasemek is also a private road and a similar request has been made by the Sembawang C.C.C, to make up this road. The U.R.S.C, cannot even consider the request until permission from the landowners has been obtained.

    The installation of street lights at Chong Sin Road from Huang Long Community Centre to Jalan Ulu Sembawang will commence in about a fortnight's time.

Column: 640

TIONG BAHRU ROAD
(Construction of new bus bay)


    The following Question stood in the name of Mr Ch'ng Jit Koon -

    3. To ask the Minister for Law and National Development when work will commence on the construction of the proposed new bus bay at Tiong Bahru Road between Seng Poh Road and Jalan Membina.

    Mr Ho Kah Leong (Jurong) rose -

    Mr Speaker: Mr Ho Kah Leong.

    Mr Ho Kah Leong: Sir, I have been asked by Mr Ch'ng Jit Koon to raise question No. 3.

Column: 641



    Mr E. W. Barker: Mr Speaker, Sir, construction work on the proposed bus bay at Tiong Bahru Road between Seng Fob Road and Jalan Membina will commence in May 1971. Funds for this purpose have been provided in the budget for the next financial year.

Column: 641

SHIN MIN PUBLIC SCHOOL
(Alternative site)


    4. Mr Ang Nam Piau asked the Minister for Law and National Develop-merit if Shin Min Public School will be affected by developments in the Sin Ming Road area, and whether and when an alternative site will be provided for the School.

    Mr E. W. Barker: Mr Speaker, Sir, the Shin Min Public School will not be affected by the proposed development in the Sin Ming Road area where about 42 acres of land are being developed by the Housing and Development Board into an industrial estate for the resettlement of motor workshops and garages.

    Mr Ang Nam Piau (Thomson): Sir, can the Minister give details of the development of the area?

    Mr Barker: Sir, about 269 motor workshops and garages which are affected by the public projects in various parts of the city will be resettled in this estate. In addition, about 500 three-room improved flats, 32 shops with living quarters, and about five eating houses will be built. I understand that the Registrar of Vehicles is also constructing a vehicle testing centre within the estate.

Column: 641

CHIT FUND COMPANY
ACTIVITIES
(Publication of Research Division's findings)


    5. Mr Hwang Soo Jin asked the Minister for Finance if he is now in a position to publish the findings of the Research Division of his Ministry into the activities of chit fund companies, and whether he now feels that the subject merits legislation and, if not, why not.

Column: 642



    The Minister of State for Finance (Mr Tang See Chim) (for the Minister for Finance): Mr Speaker, Sir, it is not intended to publish the results of the study made by my Ministry. Chit fund legislation in countries such as Ceylon, India and Taiwan is being examined with a view to similar legislation being introduced here to control the activities and operations of chit fund companies. No new chit fund companies are being allowed to be incorporated for the time being.

    Mr Hwang Soo Jin (Jalan Kayu): Sir, I would like to know why it is not intended to publish the findings of the Ministry into the activities of chit fund companies.

    Mr Tang See Chim: Mr Speaker, Sir, I thought I said that it was not intended to publish the results of the study made by my Ministry.

    Mr Hwang Soo Jin: Why?

    Mr Speaker: The Member wants to know the reasons.

    Mr Tang See Chim: Sir, this is a confidential study and it should not be made public.

    Mr Ng Kah Ting (Punggol): Can the Minister of State for Finance indicate how much public funds were spent on the confidential study?

    Mr Tang See Chim: Mr Speaker, Sir, the study was conducted by the Research Section of my Ministry and, apart from the normal salaries of the officers, no additional public funds were involved.

    Mr Ng Kah Ting: In that case, can the Minister of State make available the confidential report to those Members who wish to have a look at it?

    Mr Tang See Chim: It all depends on what the Member for Punggol meant by "those members". If he meant members of the public, the answer is no. But

    Mr Speaker: I think he meant Members of Parliament.

Column: 643



    Mr Ng Kah Ting: Yes, Sir, Members of Parliament.

    Mr Tang See Chim: Mr Speaker, Sir, I will be glad to show the results of the study to Members of Parliament who would like to have a look at them.

    Mr Hwang Soo Jin: Mr Speaker, Sir, the Minister for Finance, in replying to me in January 1970 [Vol. 29 No. 7 dated 27-1-70, col. 372], stated that he would make the findings available to the public. I am just wondering what has changed the mind of the Ministry.

    Mr Tang See Chim: Sir, I am afraid the Member for Jalan Kayu has misunderstood the Minister for Finance. I have the text of the Minister's reply to the House. If the Member would like to have a look at the study, he is welcome to it.

Column: 643

ROAD ACCIDENTS INVOLVING
DRUNKEN DRIVERS
(Particulars)


    6. Mr J. F. Conceicao asked the Minister for Home Affairs what was the frequency of road accidents involving drunken drivers, and the number of those injured and killed in such accidents, for the year ending 31st January, 1971.

    The Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Home Affairs (Mr L. P. Rodrigo) (for the Minister for Home Affairs): Mr Speaker, Sir, traffic accidents involving drunken drivers have been few and far between.

    For the year ending 31st January, 1971, there were only 21 of such cases. The frequency of these accidents thus varies from one to two accidents per month.

    Of these 21 accidents, three drivers were seriously injured in three cases. In nine other cases, the passengers of the cars driven by these drivers under the influence of alcohol sustained slight injuries. As for the remaining nine cases, no one was injured at all.

Column: 644



    Eleven drivers were prosecuted in court, resulting in six of them being convicted and five acquitted.

    The remaining cases were not brought to court owing to insufficient evidence.

    Mr Conceicao: Sir, can the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Home Affairs tell the House how these drunken drivers are identified?

    Mr Rodrigo: Mr Speaker, Sir, these drivers have their blood and urine tested for alcohol, and they are further tested to find out how competent they are still to drive at that stage. The analysis is undertaken by the Chemistry Department in accordance with the Kozelka and Hine method through a process of steam distillation.

    Mr Conceicao: Sir, can the Parliamentary Secretary inform the House whether, if the testing methods are improved, we could catch more drunken drivers?

    Mr Rodrigo: I can certainly assure the Member of that, Sir.

Column: 644

ROAD ACCIDENTS INVOLVING
PEDESTRIANS
(Particulars)


    7. Mr J. F. Conceicao asked the Minister for Home Affairs what was the frequency of traffic accidents involving pedestrians within 100 yards of a pedestrian crossing or overhead bridge, and the number of those seriously injured or killed in such accidents for the year ending 31st January, 1971.

    Mr L. P. Rodrigo (for the Minister for Home Affairs): Mr Speaker, Sir, the Traffic Police do not maintain statistics specifically relating to traffic accidents involving pedestrians and are therefore unable to state the number of accidents involving pedestrians within 100 metres of a pedestrian crossing or overhead bridge.

    However, there are records to show that for the year ending 31st January, 1971, a total of 38,139 accidents have been reported in which 152 pedestrians were killed and 1,053 seriously injured.

Column: 645



    The records show that out of the 152 pedestrians killed, three fatal accidents may be said to have occurred within 100 metres of a pedestrian crossing or overhead bridge. The motorist in one of these accidents also died from serious injuries in hospital.

2.47 p.m.

[Mr Speaker in the Chair]



    The Chairman: Third Supplementary Estimates of Expenditure for the financial year 1st April, 1970, to 31st March, 1971, contained in Paper Cmd. 5 of 1971. The summary is on page 2 of the Paper.

    Head 0107 -

    Mr J. F. Conceicao: Mr Speaker, Sir, I beg to move,

    That the sum to be allocated for Head 0107 be reduced by $10 in respect of subhead 2001*. (*The same amendment also stood in the names of Mr N Govindasamy and Mr Ng Kah Ting.)

Column: 646



    Mr Speaker, Sir, at the last budget session, I raised a query regarding this same subhead. I suggested that drivers of Government vehicles should take every care to exercise their responsibility on the road, and that we should make every effort to ensure that Government vehicles set an example of social discipline on the road. The Minister for Law gave an assurance that circulars would be sent out to Government departments to make sure that drivers make every effort to follow road regulations. The Minister agreed that drivers of Government vehicles should set an example in Singapore.

    We find now that there is a supplementary request being made for $70,000 to be used as compensation for damage caused by Government vehicles which were involved in accidents. It would be interesting for the House to know in what manner the $20,000 originally earmarked under this subhead and this $73,000 is being spent. Does this indicate that, for the past year since the last budget, there has been an increase in the number of accidents involving Government vehicles, the fault for which accidents must be attributed to the drivers of these vehicles? Or does it mean that much more is being spent this year on compensation for accidents than for any other equal length of time in previous years? If one or both of these contentions are correct, one has to renew the appeal to the Minister to take stronger measures to see that drivers of Government vehicles exercise greater care and responsibility on the road. Perhaps the sending out of circulars is not enough.

    I would like to take this opportunity of commending the Ministry of Defence on the action taken to see that its own drivers exercise greater responsibility. But from my own experience, I personally have found no discernible improvement in the driving standard of drivers of Government vehicles since the time the Minister for Law gave us the assurance that he believed that Government

Column: 647

vehicles should set a good example in Singapore. Incidentally, it would be interesting to know to what extent compensation has to be paid for damage caused in accidents involving police vehicles. Once I had the experience of seeing a police vehicle being driven in a most irresponsible way. The driver concerned was attempting to write certain notes in his notebook while driving the vehicle at the same time.

    Finally, Sir, if the amount of compensation in respect of accident claims is rising, how is it that only $25,000 has been earmarked for this same subhead in the coming financial year?

    Mr N. Govindasamy (Telok Blangah): Mr Speaker, Sir, I rise to ask the Minister for some information and clarification on the sudden increase in the provision for payment of claims against the Government arising out of accidents involving Government vehicles.

    The estimate for 1969 - 70, a period of 15 months, was $20,000; for 1970 - 71, a period of 12 months, $20,000 was earmarked: and this year, as the Member for Katong has pointed out, $25,000 has been asked for. Therefore, iii normal circumstances, an estimate of $20,000 per year would have been deemed sufficient to meet accident claims. The year 1970 - 71 has actually cost the Government, including the request for Supplementary Estimates, about $90,000 to meet accident claims involving Government vehicles. This sum, in my opinion, is abnormally high. I would therefore like to seek from the Minister the following details:

    (1) The total number of accidents involving Government vehicles for the period under review;

    (2) The breakdown of the above-mentioned total, Government department by department;

    (3) The number of successful claims against the Government and the total amount of money paid out in relation thereto;

    (4) The number of unsuccessful claims against the Government;

Column: 648



    (5) What steps, as the Member for Katong has asked, are being taken by the Government to minimise the accident rate of Government vehicles involved in accidents?

    Mr Ng Kah Ting: Mr Speaker, Sir, with all the points raised by my two colleagues, the Members for Katong and Telok Blangah, I do not think I have any ground left to cover. Anyway, would the Minister for Law and National Development care to give further information to my questions?

    The Member for Telok Blangah has just now sought clarification on the number of accident claims, successful or otherwise, and also the breakdown figures of the various Government departments involved. I would, however, like to raise some further questions:

    (1) How much was paid to each of the successful claims?

    (2) What was the number of accidents in which each of the various Government departments was involved?

    (3) Are there still any outstanding claims to be settled?

    (4) If there are, how many are there and what amount of compensation has been asked for?

    Lastly, Sir, I too share the sentiments expressed by my two colleagues in hoping that Government would take immediate steps to ensure that all Government drivers take extra caution when they are on the road. As the Member for Katong has just mentioned, they should set an example in ensuring public road safety when they are on the road.

    Mr E. W. Barker: Mr Speaker, Sir, first, let me put the record right. The Ministry of Law or the Ministry of National Development is not in charge of all Government drivers or all Government vehicles. It is when a Government vehicle is involved in an accident and there is a claim for damage that the Attorney-General steps in as the lawyer representing the Government. So whilst I agree with the Members that perhaps

Column: 649

the standard of driving of Government vehicles can be improved, what the Attorney-General can do to help is to see that circulars are sent round. These circulars have been sent round. Drivers of Government vehicles have also been educated on road safety and have been instructed to be more careful in their driving.

    As for prosecution, there is provision for the Permanent Secretary of the respective Ministry to consider, on the advice of the Attorney-General, whether disciplinary action is called for against the driver of the Government vehicle involved in an accident. It is, however, the function of the Police to determine whether the driver has committed a traffic offence. Where the Attorney- General is satisfied that the accident is due to the negligence or recklessness of the driver, he will instruct the Police to prosecute the driver concerned. There may, however, be instances where prosecution is not justified but other instructions have been contravened, in which case disciplinary action is instituted by the Permanent Secretary concerned on the advice of the Attorney- General.

    Members will agree that the expenditure that would be involved in any accident under this vote is not easily predictable. The greater the number of accidents involved, the larger will be the amount of expenditure. In the 1970 - 71 financial year, the sum of $20,000 provided has clearly proved inadequate, and another $70,000 is needed to meet expenditure of $88,475.24. To compare other years, in 1967, $13,200 was incurred; in 1968, $19,360.

3.00 p.m.

    In 1969 - 70 549,739.75 - nearly $50,000 - but still not near $90,000. For the financial year 1971 - 72, two Members have pointed out that only $25,000 has been approved. I would like to inform them that we have asked

Column: 650

for much more, but that is all we have been given, so that in the coming year they will have to hear me again.

    The number of vehicles in Singapore is increasing every year; so also are the traffic jams. In consequence, the number of accidents has increased; so has the number of accidents involving Government vehicles. The Member for Katong is not satisfied with the assurance I gave him last year. He seems to be more satisfied with what has been done in the Ministry of Defence. Am I correct?

    Mr Conceicao: Sir, I am satisfied with what the Ministry has done since the time the Minister of Defence answered my question in Parliament regarding the care that military drivers should exercise. May I make that correction, please.

    Mr Barker: I am glad to hear from the Member for Katong that he has been reassured by what has been happening in the Ministry of Defence. But now that Singapore has taken over control of the military establishments, vehicles of the Army come into the fold of the Attorney-General's Chambers in regard to expenditure on accidents. I have mentioned just now that it is the Attorney-General who acts as paymaster in respect of these claims.

    The number of accidents for the financial year 1970-71 was 875 as compared with 618 for the previous financial year. So there has definitely been an increase. The break-down of these 875 accidents is interesting: 

  Ministry of Defence                  605



  Public Health Division               111



  Ministry of Health                    30



  Public Works Department               19



  Prisons Department                    16



  Police (in which the Member

    of Katong is interested)            16



  Postmaster-General                    11



  Social Welfare Department              4



  Primary Production 

    Department                           5



  Prime Minister's Office                4


Column: 651

I can go on, but the rest do not exceed half a dozen accidents - Car Parks, Chief Surveyor's Department, or even the Fire Brigade which had two accidents. All in all, there were 875 accidents.

    I am not saying that the Ministry of Defence drivers are careless, but the figures are there. As the British pull out, we have to have more and more vehicles, more and more drivers; and therefore more and more accidents occur. Hence, we are asking for this supplementary vote.

    Of the number of persons involved in these 875 accidents, 10 were killed and 119 injured. Of these 875 claims, 224 were successfully settled out of court. A total of 615 cases, including 15 police cases, were unsuccessful, involving a total sum of $88,475.24. The police cases cost $7,584.54. A total of 36 cases, involving claims amounting to about $35,000, are still pending.

    I have no further information for Members, but I understand that the Member for Katong is a member of the National Safety First Council!

    Mr Conceicao: The Member for Katong is not a member of the National Safety First Council. He is only an adviser!

    Mr Ng Kah Ting: Sir, arising out of the answers given, I just want further clarification if the Minister would care to answer me.

    Mr Barker: If I have the information.

    Mr Ng Kah Ting: Mr Speaker, Sir, it would appear that the Ministry of Defence and the Ministry of Health, in particular, have the highest number of accidents. In view of this, are these two Ministries taking steps to ensure that their drivers undergo a road safety course?

    Sir, I also wonder whether the Minister for Law and National Development will consider insuring all Government vehicles against accidents, and whether

Column: 652

any feasibility study has been made in this respect. I believe that this will take some load off the Attorney-General's Chambers.

    The Minister for Education (Mr Lim Kim San): $1 million insurance!

    Mr Barker: Sir, I cannot speak for either the Minister for Health or the Minister of Defence, but I am sure they will take into consideration the Member's suggestion. Speaking for myself, my Ministry will take his suggestion into consideration.

    Mr Ng Kah Ting: What about insurance?

    Mr Barker: We will consider it.

    Mr Conceicao: Mr Speaker, Sir, I beg leave to withdraw my amendment.

    Amendment, by leave, withdrawn.

    The sum of $70,000 for Head 0107 ordered to stand part of the Third Supplementary Estimates of Expenditure for the financial year 1st April, 1970, to 31st March, 1971.

Column: 652



    Head 0701 -

    Mr N. Govindasamy: Mr Speaker, Sir, I beg to move,

    That the sum to be allocated for Head 0701 be reduced by $10 in respect of subhead 1*.

    (* The same amendment also stood in the name of Mr Ng Kah Ting.)

    Sir, I am pleased to learn that the Ministry of Education has been able to fill a greater number of its vacant posts than was anticipated by the Ministry. This amendment is moved in order to seek further clarification on the posts that the Ministry has been able to fill.

    Sir, in my opinion, the Ministry should fill not only the vacancies in the promotion grades but also the many vacancies in the lower grades of the teaching service. Last year the estimate for Substitute Relief Teachers alone was $1.3 million in the General Education Department. In answering a supplementary question on relief teachers last

Column: 653

week, the Minister of State for Education said that the phenomenon of relief teachers will continue to exist so long as teachers continue to take maternity leave.

    Sir, I have been a teacher for many years, and maternity leave is not a new concept. It has been there all along. The reason for the employment of relief teachers now is due to the shortage of teachers and not that teachers take maternity leave. The position obtaining then was that every school had a quota of teachers over and above the number that would be needed for all the classrooms. If any teacher went on long leave or maternity leave, there would be sufficient qualified teachers to stand in. Because of this quota of teachers in each school, I deem this number to be vacancies in the school as well. The question is: will the Ministry attempt to fill not only the vacant posts in the promotion grades, but also the shortage of teachers in schools?

    Mr Ng Kah Ting: Mr Speaker, Sir, I too seek information similar to that asked for by the Member for Telok Blangah.

    Parliament is being asked to approve a sum of slightly over half a million dollars for the payment of personal emoluments. I find that the explanatory note in the Command Paper on these supplementary estimates is not clear. Therefore, I will be grateful if the Minister for Education will indicate the number of vacant posts in the last financial year, i.e., ending this month; how many have been filled, and what are the categories of vacancies that have been filled. Further, are there still vacancies to be filled? If so, what are they, and in what categories?

    Sir, the Member for Telok Blangah is of the opinion that not only the vacant posts in the higher categories should be filled, but also those in the lower categories should be filled as well. I take it that he means the administrative

Column: 654

service as well as the teaching service. On that note, Sir, I reserve some further questions, pending the answers from the Minister for Education.

    Mr Lim Kim San: Mr Speaker, Sir, I heartily agree with the Member for Telok Blangah that maternity leave is not a new phenomenon. But I would like to remind him that in the clarification given by the Minister of State for Education to the supplementary question as to when the system of relief teachers was instituted, I think the Minister of State replied, "Ever since maternity leave was granted." There is nothing wrong with that.

    Sir, I am not able to give in detail the categories of vacancies which have been filled. But, generally speaking, we have vacancies right through the service - from principals to teachers, to specialists, to specialist teachers, to administrative officers, to inspectors of schools, to inspectors, and even higher clerical officers.
